Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Story: I was still thinking about the text from my boyfriend as I pulled on my gloves and mask for my shift. He thought I’d promised to spend Saturday with him, but I’d only said I’d try. Now he was upset, and I could feel the tension in every message. I wanted to call him, to clear things up before it grew into something bigger, but I was already late for my cleaning round. My supervisor had just reminded us—no exceptions on safety protocols. Gloves, mask, sanitizer, every room, every time. I couldn’t risk a warning or, worse, losing my job. But my phone kept buzzing in my pocket, and I knew he was waiting for an answer, expecting me to fix things like I always did. My hands shook as I sprayed disinfectant, torn between the urge to step out and call him, and the strict rules I was expected to follow. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
